items.title: Allow disabling argument inference
items.body:
I have a wrapper that I use to provide common arguments (among other things):
```
def cli(func):
    @wraps(func)
    @arg('--config', help='path to config')
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        ...
        return func(*args, **kwargs)
    return wrapper
```

```
@arg('--name', help='Filter to hosts with this name', default=None)
@cli
def describe(config, name=None) -> List[Dict[str, Any]]:
 .....
```

The problem is `*args` is inferred to be a variable-length positional argument, whenever I use `@cli`:

```
usage: aww.py describe [-h] [--name NAME] [--config CONFIG]
                       [args [args ...]]

    List EC2 instances in the region


positional arguments:
  args               -

optional arguments:
  -h, --help         show this help message and exit
  --name NAME        Filter to hosts with this name (default: -)
  --config CONFIG  path to config
```

If I could disable argument inference from the signature, this would be solved!

items.title: Decorated functions don't work through __wrapped__ when using argh.named or when using a namespace
Avoiding namespace collisions for command names
items.body:
I really like Argh and have used it for several projects. I've often found myself contorting my subcommand names to avoid namespace collisions. For example, today I want to write a `filter` subcommand, but defining a function with this name would be bad practice.

Is there a recommended workaround for this issue? One way could be to truncate trailing underscores from CLI function names (which are converted to dashes currently by Argh)

If this were the case it would be possible to define a function `filter_()` which was then called as the subcommand `filter`.

items.title: Confusing license information
items.body: The repository contains both the GPLv3 (COPYING) as well as the LGPL 3 (COPYING.LESSER) license text. Github seems to use COPYING to label the repo as GPLv3 project (see https://github.com/neithere/argh/blob/master/COPYING): As the README states > Argh is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the GNU Lesser General Public License as published by the Free Software Foundation, either version 3 of the License, or (at your option) any later version. file COPYING should be removed from the repository to avoid confusion - both from users as well as from Github's license detection algorithm.

items.title: Decorated functions don't introspect through __wrapped__
Destination `dest` option throwing error
items.body:
Hi,

Im trying to include a 'dest' option:

``` python
import argparse
import argh
from argh import arg

@arg('--foo', dest='bar')
def f(foo=None):
    pass

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
argh.set_default_command(parser, f)
argh.dispatch(parser)
```

However im getting an error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/josh/.PyCharm2016.2/config/scratches/scratch_21.py", line 12, in <module>
    argh.set_default_command(parser, f)
  File "/home/josh/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/argh/assembling.py", line 287, in set_default_command
    sig=', '.join('/'.join(x) for x in xs)))
argh.exceptions.AssemblingError: f: argument --foo does not fit function signature: -f/--foo
```

Im using version v0.26.2. Any ideas?

BTW Great package - I've been looking for something like this for a while

items.title: Bug in the way **kwargs is handled
items.body:
A nasty situation occurs when `**kwargs` is present in a dispatched function and positionals without defaults contain underscores. Positional argument `foo_bar` is added to the parser as `foo-bar` and gets listed as `foo-bar` in the resultant Namespace objects. [This code](https://github.com/neithere/argh/blob/master/argh/dispatching.py#L254-L257) fails to account for the hyphens and you therefore get some wacky stuff happening:

``` python
import argh

def f(foo_foo, bar_bar, baz_baz=5, **kwargs):
    print('foo:', foo_foo, 'bar:', bar_bar, 'baz:', baz_baz)
    print(kwargs)

argh.dispatch_command(f)
```

Running this yields

```
$ python script.py abc def
foo: abc bar: def baz: 5
{'bar-bar': 'def', 'foo-foo': 'abc'}
```

There are two ways to fix this:
- (Much simpler) add non-flag arguments to the parser without underscore -> hyphen replacement
- (A bit more complicated but not too bad) Fix the above-linked code to properly account for the presence of hyphens, i.e. splitting `spec.args` into defaults/no-defaults lists and replacing underscores in the no-defaults list with hyphens

I'll submit a PR for the simpler case, but if there's strong opinions I can change to option 2.

items.title: argh.decorators.arg documentation unclear
items.body:
Hello! I'm not able to figure this out:
In the [API Reference about @arg](http://argh.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference.html?highlight=add_argument#argh.decorators.arg) you def like:
`def load(args):` and then have `args.format` available in the function.

That looks awesome but ... I cannot reproduce this. It always says:
`argh.exceptions.AssemblingError: load: argument path does not fit function signature: args`

I even tried to look up [how you test this](https://github.com/neithere/argh/blob/master/test/test_decorators.py): Turns out you don't have any args set up in the `func`s

And how do you get to `@arg`? is it:
`from argh.decorators import arg` ?
Is this the same:
`@argh.arg` ? like in the test?

items.title: Full text of license is missing
items.body: Argh source doesn't include full text of license and it should. LGPLv3 consist of GPLv3 and LGPLv3 with additional permissions. Two files separately or merged one should be added (e.g. like on https://github.com/mezuro/kalibro_entities COPYING and COPYING.LESSER).

items.title: Allow multiple values for an option
items.body:
I'm building a command line interface and would like to be able to repeat the same command and get that collected as a list, i.e.:

`myapp --filter some-value --filter some-other-value`

By default if the `filter` parameter is a string you only get the last value (in the example above `some-other-value`), if it is defined as a list then you get again the same value but as a list :-/

items.title: allow using a default command with multiple commands
items.body:
http://argh.readthedocs.org/en/latest/tutorial.html#single-command-application shows how to use the default command function. This is a little misleading in that we're building an app with a single command, but what do you do to create an app with mulitple commands, one of which is a default and assumed if not provided?

Maybe this was considered, but is not possible? Or maybe it is possible already, in another way I have not seen (in which case I would propose a doc update).

It would be nice to have the ability to setup something like:

```
import argh
from app.cli import app, cmd1, cmd2

def main():
    p = argh.ArghParser()
    argh.set_default_command(p, app)
    p.add_commands([cmd1, cmd2])
    p.dispatch()
```

Usage would be something like: `app --help` or `app cmd1` or `app cmd2` - `app` infers `app app`.

The current way I understand things, would result in `app app` to run the 'default'

items.title: document using argh with python-setuptools entry_points
items.body:
Hi,

I've been using argh in a few ways, but I've been unable to figure out how to properly use argh with python's entry_points (provided by setuptools). EG, something like:

```
from setuptools import setup
console_scripts = ['app = app.cli:main', 'app-foo = app.cli.foo']
setup(...  entry_points = { 'console_scripts': console_scripts })
```

Is argh compatible with python's entry points? Am I making a mistake in trying to use these two together? Thanks for a great library!

items.title: Make generated --help text show default values
items.body:
Hi!

I have a program which takes ~20 numerical parameters at start and I would like
to show the default of each of these in the `--help` output.

a stripped down exapmle:

```
import argh

def greet(name="Sir"):
    print("Hello " + name + "!")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    argh.dispatch_command(greet)
```

`python greeter.py --help` --->

```
usage: greeter.py [-h] [-n NAME]

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -n NAME, --name NAME
```

where I would like to be able to make argh do something like:

```
usage: greeter.py [-h] [-n NAME]

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -n NAME, --name NAME (default: "Sir")
```

Is this functionality already available? (I failed to find it reading the docs)
If not, is it hard to implement? I could volunteer to try and send a PR (if it's a wanted feature).

Thanks!
Björn

items.title: RFE: support I18N
items.body:
Hello all.

I'm currently using argh for some CLI scripts and enjoying it greatly. I have one question though: Can I somehow localize help strings and descriptions? Maybe using callbacks? I.e.:

``` python
@arg('argument', help=_('Arg Help Text')) # notice the _()
def some_func():
    ...
```

And later in the code (this is based on pyramid translationstrings, but can be anything):

``` python
def localize(string):
        if isinstance(string, TranslationString):
            string = loc.translate(string)
    return string

parser.set_i18n_callback(localize)
```

Maybe even allow passing some context object, to get rid of global variable access (`loc` in my example above).

items.title: Function docstring formatting not preserved and argument defaults not shown
items.body:
Per default argh does not preserve the formatting of the function’s docstring and does not print the default argument values in the help message invoked with `--help` (I'm using version 0.24.1). 

A more elaborate description of the problem, together with some solution attempts can be found here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23567393/pythons-argh-library-preserve-docstring-formatting-in-help-message

To solve the first issue, a customized Formatter class could be defined which combines `ArgumentDefaultsHelpFormatter` and `RawDescriptionHelpFormatter` in `constants.py`:

``` python
class CustomFormatter(argparse.ArgumentDefaultsHelpFormatter,
                      argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter)
    pass

PARSER_FORMATTER = CustomFormatter
```

As for the second issue, the argument defaults are only displayed if a `@arg(var, help="%(default)s")` decorator is used for every variable. It would be much nicer however if this worked out of the box without the need for any decorator. In the above link this problem was solved by defining a custom decorator which internally sets the `help="%(default)s"` option for each argument.

items.title: Warnings about argcomplete (?)
items.body:
I get annoying warnings all the time:

``` bash
$ ./blah 
/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.6/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/argh/completion.py:90: UserWarning: Bash completion not available. Install argcomplete.
  warnings.warn('Bash completion not available. Install argcomplete.')
usage: blah [-h] {test} ...
blah: error: too few arguments

$ ./blah test
/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.6/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/argh/completion.py:90: UserWarning: Bash completion not available. Install argcomplete.
  warnings.warn('Bash completion not available. Install argcomplete.')
test
```

My python script is:

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python
import argh

def test():
    print 'test'

parser = argh.ArghParser()
parser.add_commands([test])

if __name__ == '__main__':
    parser.dispatch()
```

What is this warning about ? I don't really care about bash completion.

Thanks

 subparsers = parser.add_subparsers()

items.title: Optionally permit unknown args
items.body:
Hi,

It'd be useful if there was a way of permitting unknown args. This can be done by conditionally calling `args, unknown = parser.parse_known_args(argv, namespace=namespace)` instead of always calling `parser.parse_args()`.

Also see: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12818146/python-argparse-ignore-unrecognised-arguments

Thanks

hello,

thanks!

items.title: Argcomplete support is broken
items.body:
Test script:

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python
# PYTHON_ARGCOMPLETE_OK
import argh

def f(foo, bar=123):
    print('foo', foo, '--bar', bar)

argh.dispatch_command(f)
```

Output (`[tab]` stands for `tab` key press):

``` bash
$ ./completion.py [tab]usage: completion.py [-h] [-b BAR] foo
completion.py: error: the following arguments are required: foo
Non-zero exit
$ ./completion.py one -[tab]usage: completion.py [-h] [-b BAR] foo
completion.py: error: the following arguments are required: foo
Non-zero exit
```

This is apparently since 549439eea038d2ad1c9b0e505853ca073f95303d. Not surfaced before probably due to some changes in argcomplete.

items.title: Python 3: arguments lost in edge cases
items.body:
``` python
import argh
def process(*points, parameter=0):
  print(points, parameter) # STUB

if __name__ == '__main__':
  argh.dispatch_command(process)
```

`argh` does not detect `parameter` as an argument and does not allow me to

```
python3.3 test.py a b c --parameter=3
```

items.title: Option/argument with underscore matching fails even if `dest` value matches parameter name
items.body:
I'm not sure whether this is a bug or an API design decision or I'm making some obvious mistake. I can't force match between decorator defined option and function argument. They contain hyphens and underscores. I tried to set this with `dest` value:

```
import argh                                                                      

@argh.arg('--long-option', dest='long_option')                                   
def command(long_option):                                                        
    pass                                                                         

 argh.ArghParser().add_commands([command])
```

above snippet raises: `ValueError: command: argument --long-option does not fit function signature: long-option`

Shorter version also fails, but I understand that it is not so explicit:

```
@argh.arg('--long-option')                                                       
def command(long_option):                                                        
    pass 
```

I'm aware that parsing and matching arguments can lead to many ambiguities, so maybe there is other way to force such option naming. Can I add options to parser manually and force my naming (maybe I've missed this in docs)?

items.title: More informative exception on explicit vs inferred arg type clash
items.body:
I see in the documentation that underscores are converted to hyphens, but this seems to happen only for positional arguments. I seem to be unable to create optional arguments with either hyphens or underscores. For example:

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python
import argparse,argcomplete,argh

@argh.arg('--my_switch', default="full")
def mycommand(my_switch):
    print("Hello world.")

parser = argh.ArghParser()
parser.add_commands([mycommand])
argh.completion.autocomplete(parser)
parser.dispatch()
```

outputs:

```
ValueError: mycommand: argument --my_switch does not fit function signature: my-switch
```

whereas this works fine:

``` python
@argh.arg('--myswitch', default="full")
def mycommand(myswitch):
```

How do I create an optional parameter with either a hyphen or an underscore?

items.title: Migrate code and issues from Bitbucket to Github
items.body:
Reason: there's no free CI service available for Bitbucket that could build under multiple Python versions at once.
In Github there's Travis.

items.title: Disable completion when not attached to a TTY
items.body:
I'm using argh as a dependency of the watchdog project. When I daemonise my watchdog process, I end up with the bash warnings in my logfile (as per [#39](https://bitbucket.org/neithere/argh/issue/39/dont-issue-bash-warnings-when-not-using)).

This is easily handled with something like the following:

``` diff

@@ -84,7 +84,7 @@ def dispatch(parser, argv=None, add_help_command=True,
     You can also mark arbitrary exceptions as "wrappable" by using the
     :func:`~argh.decorators.wrap_errors` decorator.
     """
-    if completion:
+    if completion and sys.stdout.isatty():
         autocomplete(parser)
```

Apologies for the lack of a pull req; I had a quick look but I'm unfamiliar with Bitbucket and I've never touched Mercurial :)

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @mafrosis on 2013-08-20 02:09:01+00:00, last updated: 2013-08-20 08:39:17+00:00

Is this possible to add this quite helpful functionality to argh?

items.title: Argparse dependency
items.body:
Hi,

thanks for making argh, it is really great ! I am using it for [sigal](https://github.com/saimn/sigal/) but I have an issue when packaging it for Archlinux. When calling sigal I get the following error:

```
#!python

pkg_resources.DistributionNotFound: argparse>=1.1
```

This is because you are adding argparse as a dependency in your setup.py even for python 2.7. So when installing argh with the system package I have a file `/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/argh-0.23.0-py2.7.egg-info/requires.txt` which contains argparse. And when calling my command with the entry_point system, it checks this dependency and fails.

Could you change your setup.py to add argparse only for python 2.6 ?

items.title: Don't issue bash warnings when not using bash
items.body:
It would be nice if the warnings were only issued if you're running bash.  Perhaps, something like the following?

``` diff

diff --git i/argh/completion.py w/argh/completion.py
index 82febd0..0624310 100644
--- i/argh/completion.py
+++ w/argh/completion.py
@@ -77,8 +77,9 @@ def autocomplete(parser):
     """ Adds support for shell completion by patching given
     `argparse.ArgumentParser` (sub)class.
     """
+    import os
     if COMPLETION_ENABLED:
         argcomplete.autocomplete(parser)
-    else:
+    elif os.getenv('BASH'):
         import warnings
         warnings.warn('Bash completion not available. Install argcomplete.')

```

Thanks,

James

PS. FWIW, the GitHub mirror appears to be far _far_ behind this repo.

items.title: Wrapped errors should go to stderr
items.body:
# Use case

``` python
db = {'a': 1}

@wrap_errors([KeyError])
def func(key):
    return db[key]
```

``` bash
$ app a
→ stdout: 1
→ stderr:

$ app b
→ stdout:
→ stderr: KeyError: 'b'
```
# Motivation

The use case above implies that the command output may be redirected to another command or a file. Current implementation would have the following negative effect:
1. the user will be unaware of the error;
2. the error message will be misinterpreted as an actually retrieved value and processed, generating a further error somewhere in the toolchain.
# Solution

Normal flow and catched errors should be separated in the dispatcher.
- If an error is wrapped, the result should go to the object defined as `dispatch(errors_file=sys.stderr)`.
- The rest goes to the object defined as `dispatch(output_file=sys.stdout)`.

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @neithere on 2013-01-14 10:18:47+00:00, last updated: 2013-01-30 01:06:04+00:00

items.title: Specify preprocessor for wrapped errors
items.body:
Use cases:
- every wrapped error should be printed in red colour.
- every wrapped error should have the prefix "ERR:".

Example code:

```
import termcolor

def format_error(excinfo):
    return termcolor.colored('ERR: {0}!'.format(excinfo), 'red')

@wrap_errors([KeyError], processor=format_error)
def func(key):
    return db[key]
```

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @neithere on 2013-01-14 05:54:56+00:00, last updated: 2013-01-14 06:57:17+00:00

items.title: Remove argh.six
items.body:
# Problem
1. Licensing issue: Argh is published under LGPL, Six is under MIT. It may or may not be a problem, IANAL.
2. Currently Argh relies on: six.PY3, six.string_types, six.text_type, six.binary_type, six.BytesIO, six.StringIO. This stuff is trivial and does not require 12K worth of code or an external dependency. It's very unlikely that Argh is ever going to require anything else from _six_.
# Solution

There are two possible solutions:
1. add http://pypi.python.org/pypi/six/ as an external dependency;
2. completely remove it and stick to a simple chunk of code. (PREFERRED)

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @neithere on 2013-01-01 18:30:43+00:00, last updated: 2013-01-01 23:34:04+00:00

items.title: Argh fails with parameter action type 'count' if a default value is provided
items.body:
Consider the following code:

```
#!python
@arg('-v', '--verbose',
     dest='verbose',
     action='count',
     default=0,
     help="Display verbose output.")
def cmd(foo, bar=1, *args, **kwargs):
    yield kwargs.get('verbose', -1)
    yield foo
    yield bar
    yield ', '.join(args)

# dispatching:
parser = ArghParser()
parser.add_commands([cmd])

if __name__ == '__main__':
    parser.dispatch()
```

Running this code throws the following exception:

```
#!pytb
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".\engineer_script.py", line 37, in <module>
    parser.add_commands([cmd])
  File "C:\Users\Tyler\.virtualenvs\engineer-dev\lib\site-packages\argh\helpers.py", line 40, in add_commands
    return add_commands(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\Tyler\.virtualenvs\engineer-dev\lib\site-packages\argh\assembling.py", line 373, in add_commands
    set_default_command(command_parser, func)
  File "C:\Users\Tyler\.virtualenvs\engineer-dev\lib\site-packages\argh\assembling.py", line 266, in set_default_command
    args='/'.join(dest_or_opt_strings), func=function.__name__, msg=e))
TypeError: cmd: cannot add arg -v/--verbose: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'type'
```

Removing the `default=0` parameter from the `arg` decorator works, but then the default is set to `None`, which is not ideal.

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @tylerbutler on 2012-12-31 22:46:04+00:00, last updated: 2012-12-31 23:34:25+00:00

items.title: Refactoring
Indicate argument that caused error during add_argument
items.body:
In set_default_command, ArgumentParser.add_argument is called in a loop with arguments that had otherwise not been validate. If any of these calls are found invalid, insufficient context is given in the exception TraceBack to determine which argument definition is broken. The add_argument call should hence be wrapped with a try-except that gives some context (i.e. what args and kwargs caused the error) and reraises the exception.

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @jnothman on 2012-11-22 04:33:10+00:00, last updated: 2012-12-23 03:52:23+00:00

Tests fail in Python 3.3+
items.body:

```
1) ERROR: A command can be resolved to a function, not a namespace.

   Traceback (most recent call last):
    tests.py line 172 in test_bare_namespace
      self.assert_cmd_fails('greet', 'too few arguments')
    tests.py line 130 in assert_cmd_fails
      self.assert_cmd_exits(command_string, message_regex)
    tests.py line 126 in assert_cmd_exits
      self.assertRaisesRegexp(SystemExit, message_regex, f)
    tests.py line 125 in <lambda>
      f = lambda: self.parser.dispatch(command_string.split())
    argh/helpers.py line 403 in dispatch
      return dispatch(self, *args, **kwargs)
    argh/helpers.py line 295 in dispatch
      f.write(output)
   TypeError: TypeError: string argument expected, got 'bytes'
```

items.title: dispatch() can't write to stdout under python 3(.2)
items.body:
I'm not 100% about this, as it seems like basic functionality, but when porting some code that uses argh to python 3.2 I have the following problem:

code looking like:

```
p = ArghParser()
p.add_commands([convert, catalog, clean,  mv,  cp],  namespace='charts', title="Convert, catalog and move")

try:
    p.dispatch()
...
```

(where 'convert' yields a _string_)

results in:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/jcs/src/jknav/jacknife-sdk/lib/jk.py", line 333, in <module>
    p.dispatch()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.2/site-packages/argh-0.15.0-py3.2.egg/argh/helpers.py", line 304, in dispatch
    return dispatch(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.2/site-packages/argh-0.15.0-py3.2.egg/argh/helpers.py", line 205, in dispatch
    f.write(output)
TypeError: must be str, not bytes
```

'output' does seem to be a byte array, not string, at line 205 in dispatch()

I worked around this with a change of my call to dispatch():

```
    p.dispatch( output_file=open('/dev/stdout', 'wb') )
```

but this is clearly non-portable and undesirable. perhaps I am missing something obvious??

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by [jcs](https://bitbucket.org/jcs) on 2012-03-13 20:55:56+00:00, last updated: 2012-12-17 03:27:05+00:00

Perhaps it's just a documentation failing, but I can't see how to use argh for what must be the most common case: a script with no subcommands. Can this be done easily? I want to be able to say e.g:

```
from argh import arg, dispatch

@arg('--foo', default=1)
def main(args):
    print args.foo

dispatch(my_function)
```

and then run `python myscript.py --foo 2` or `-h`. Thanks!

items.title: @command broken if 2+ arguments start with same character
items.body:
Example:

```
#!python
@command
def my_command(skip_foo=False, skip_bar=False):
    pass
```

Result:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/andy/example.py", line 44, in <module>
    my_command
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/argh/helpers.py", line 297, in add_commands
    return add_commands(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/argh/helpers.py", line 115, in add_commands
    command_parser.add_argument(*a_args, **a_kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/argparse.py", line 1287, in add_argument
    return self._add_action(action)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/argparse.py", line 1661, in _add_action
    self._optionals._add_action(action)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/argparse.py", line 1488, in _add_action
    action = super(_ArgumentGroup, self)._add_action(action)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/argparse.py", line 1301, in _add_action
    self._check_conflict(action)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/argparse.py", line 1439, in _check_conflict
    conflict_handler(action, confl_optionals)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/argparse.py", line 1446, in _handle_conflict_error
    raise ArgumentError(action, message % conflict_string)
argparse.ArgumentError: argument -s/--skip_foo: conflicting option string(s): -s
```

Possible solutions:
1. omit short names for all arguments created by @command (may be excessive);
2. omit short names for conflicting arguments;
3. omit short names for all but the first of the conflicting arguments (but will the first always remain first?);
4. generate short names for conflicting arguments from other chars (but we thus cannot guarantee the stability of the API as the order of the arguments may change; also the solution seems to be too complex).

I'd prefer the 2nd solution.

P.S.: don't forget unittests.

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @neithere on 2011-09-03 12:28:56+00:00, last updated: 2012-12-23 03:29:06+00:00

items.title: Coercing strings to Unicode
items.body:
This fails:

``` python
@arg('foo', type=unicode)
def xyz(args):
    print args.foo
```

``` shell
./app.py xyz привет!
```

So we have to decode _str_ objects to _utf-8_ every time for every Unicode argument. This is very annoying. Argh should at least provide a `fix_unicode(ns, *list_of_args)` function or somehow handle the coercion when `type=unicode` is specified (maybe by forcing `type=str`, setting a flag and adding a custom namespace object).

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @neithere on 2011-01-05 13:44:19+00:00, last updated: 2012-12-18 15:01:56+00:00

items.title: Configurable output stream
items.body:
Mika Eloranta: //Adding another dispatch() parameter 'output_file' (default: sys.stdout) where all output would be written with .write() would 1) be handy in some use cases and 2) could be used in test automation (write output to a temp file or a pipe and read it from there).//

items.title: [Feature request] Generate bash-completion support

milestone.description:
First release with significant changes, maybe backwards-incompatible.
The schedule may float because it's less important than features.

items.body:
hi,

I'd really like if argh had the ability to
allow bash to complete commands/options provided
by argh. That would really make it easier for 
users to issue commands running python programs.

Would it possible to add such a thing to argh?

Thank you. =)
Cheers.

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @gorakhargosh on 2010-12-01 18:01:12+00:00, last updated: 2010-12-01 18:24:50+00:00

items.title: Installation fails on Python 2.5
items.body:
I'm using argh as a dependency for http://github.com/gorakhargosh/watchdog and when installing argh as a dependency using python2.5 I see this traceback:

{{{
# !python

Searching for argh>=0.6.0
Reading http://pypi.python.org/simple/argh/
Reading http://bitbucket.org/neithere/argh/
Reading http://bitbucket.org/neithere/argh/src/
Best match: argh 0.8.0
Downloading http://pypi.python.org/packages/source/a/argh/argh-0.8.0.tar.gz#md5=e2733be992b788d57fa18795c9622d53
Processing argh-0.8.0.tar.gz
Running argh-0.8.0/setup.py -q bdist_egg --dist-dir /tmp/easy_install-XSVX1J/argh-0.8.0/egg-dist-tmp-NoEKoD
  File "build/bdist.macosx-10.6-i386/egg/argh/**init**.py", line 16
    from .exceptions import *
SyntaxError: 'import *' not allowed with 'from .'

build/bdist.macosx-10.6-i386/egg/argh/helpers.py:186: Warning: 'as' will become a reserved keyword in Python 2.6
  File "build/bdist.macosx-10.6-i386/egg/argh/helpers.py", line 186
    except CommandError as e:
                         ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax

}}}

**Note**: This issue has been automatically migrated from Bitbucket
Created by @gorakhargosh on 2010-11-27 11:44:34+00:00, last updated: 2010-11-27 12:25:30+00:00
